Native leaders warn that freezing of federal funds could imperil some services
Native American leaders said they’re worried about the impact of a freeze on federal grants and loans that could affect dozens of programs that provide a range of services including food, health care, education, housing and law enforcement.
The United States has more than 570 federally recognized tribes, and many receive some type of funds to provide programs and services for their tribal citizens through the federal government.
Advocates and leaders in tribal communities said they’re concerned that many tribes are not in a financial position to fully fund their citizens’ needs without federal money.
“Everybody is scrambling in Indian Country,” said Brian Weeden, chairman of the Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe in Massachusetts, which has about 4,000 enrolled citizens and whose tribe receives grant funds from the federal government.
“Tribes are trying to figure it out,” he said, “and draw down programs to make sure they can stay afloat.”
Josh Arce, president and chief executive of Partnership with Native Americans — a nonprofit group that provides services and aid to more than 150 tribal communities in remote areas of the Southwest and northern plains — said “we’re pretty surprised” about the freeze.
“It’s not something we thought we’d wake up to on a Tuesday morning,” he said, “and it could impact so many things for Native American communities, from road and bridge programs to childhood education and nutrition efforts for the elderly.”
Arce said some tribes use the federal grants for much-needed services, and “if they don’t have the ability to offset the loss, we don’t know what that could look like for continuing essential programs or starting new programs for the year.”
“That means communities that have basic needs could see those needs go unmet,” he said. Programs that pay for firewood or propane gas to heat homes or distribute food could be hurt, he said.
